results.title: Girl in danger: The Case of a pre-delinquent girl
results.creator_credit: Robert Anderson and Robert Anderson Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Disordered Mind”.
Psychiatrists Dr. June Cumberland and Dr. S.J. Shamsie interview Susan, a thirteen year old girl on the verge of becoming a delinquent. Susan’s parents are also interviewed. Susan is intelligent and a leader; she is thirteen but looks eighteen, and emotionally most of the time is nearer six. She becomes a problem for her parents, her school and herself: she is apparently rushing toward delinquency. Her behaviour is discussed with police, her teachers and in counselling sessions with Susan and her parents. Susan still has problems after seven months of treatment but she has learned how to handle them with more maturity, and has a better relationship with her parents.

results.title: Aggressive child: a pre-school behaviour child
results.creator_credit: Robert Anderson and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Disordered Mind”.
Philip, an attractive, intelligent six year old is always in trouble at home and at school because of his aggressive behaviour. At the suggestion of the school authorities his mother takes him to a child psychiatrist, who discovers that his fighting covers deep-seated anxieties. We see the psychiatrists Dr. Hyman Caplan, Dr. June Cumberland and Dr. Taylor Statten counselling Philip and his mother, and the boy’s teachers discussing his change in behaviour following several months of treatment.

results.title: Building belief. Pt. 2
results.creator_credit: Dana H. Hodgdon, Bernice Gregorio and Northwestern University Film Library
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dorothy Heathcote Teaching series”.
Dorothy Heathcote continues her work with a class of nine and ten year old American children. Using drama to create focus and feeling, she poses three moral dilemmas, where the children are confronted with crises involving leadership, old-age, and death. Suitable for teachers and tertiary level.

results.title: Building belief. Pt. 1
results.creator_credit: Dana H. Hodgdon, Bernice Gregorio and Northwestern University Film Library
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dorothy Heathcote Teaching series”.
This film shows England’s outstanding drama educator, Dorothy Heathcote, working with nine and ten year old American children. She uses drama as a means of teaching social studies. Suitable for teachers and tertiary level.

results.title: Dorothy Heathcote talks to teachers. Pt. 2 (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Dana H. Hodgdon, Bernice Gregorio and Northwestern University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dorothy Heathcote Teaching series”.
Drama in the classroom continues with the discussion of techniques developed by Mrs. Heathcote. “Questioning”, “storyline”, “universals” and “brother hoods” are examined. Drama is related to developing language and social skills, while teaching subject material. Mrs. Heathcote’s educative process is based on total involvement that ultimately modifies behaviour.

results.title: Glass curtain
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Doris Chase Concepts”.
A dance film in which a woman tries to cope with the dimming mind of her mother who suffers from Alzheimer’s disease. Dancer Jennie Ventriss. Music by Katherine Hoover.

results.title: The Mehinacu
results.creator_credit: Carlos Pasini and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Disappearing world”.
The men and women of the Mehinacu, in central Brazil, live harmoniously in the five family houses of their small village, but conflict and separation of the sexes is an everyday fact of life - with the men and women performing distinctly different roles and tasks in order to thrive together. This film is a record of the elaborate rituals that take a month to complete, and are central to the Mehinacu way of life - a unique and colourful system of custom and taboo that may not survive the modern world.

results.title: Masai manhood
results.creator_credit: Chris Curling and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Disappearing world”.
Shows the process of attaining maturity for men in the Masai tribes. Starting in the late teens the young men serve seven years as ‘Moran’ or warriors. The end of their adolescence is celebrated at a spectacular ceremony- ‘Eunoto’ - which formally prepares the Moran to take their place as mature members of the tribe.
